author: ThankYouHuma2016
body: Intel’s chip technology is years behind the other big boys and Apple has now ditched them entirely. TSMC makes the chips for Apple, AMD, NVDA, Marvell, Qualcomm, Broadcom, and basically any other chip company you can think of.

author: Vanilla_Actual
body:
Sit back and enjoy your day. I’m not attacking you. I do agree many  stimulus boosted stocks are overvalued. 
So are many tech stocks. NVDA, ASML. TSLA,ROKU, AMD all fit that description imo. But companies like AVGO, AMAT, LRCX, KLAC are good growth stocks even here. 

WS is suggesting tht ppl take their money out of stocks like LRCX with a p/e in the 20s and an outstanding balance sheet and fwd growth both short and long term and buy into “re opening” stocks like ELY and BAC with p/e in the the 40s? Not likely to grow like SMEs.
On what planet is this good investment advice?  And yes I own shares of LRCX. Just sold all of my BAC shares.

author: GeezWhizGuys
body: I trimmed some and been buying dips. I'm holding LCRX, NVDA, AMD, AVGO. AVGO may be the best of these rn

author: felunk
body: On long enough time frame hard to go wrong but since AMD doesnt pay a dividend its hard to hold it unlike Intel, NVDA, AVGO, QCOM, etc etc....which pay you to hold for the inevitable boom/bust cycles...

author: andrwsc
body:
> Do you think in 10 years these will be the same stocks if you use the exact same metric? Of course you don't. So how will you adjust your portfolio? If you used the metric you used above to construct a portfolio for 2015, how many of the stocks you just listed above would be in your that portfolio?

This is an excellent question.  I went back to my spreadsheet and disregarded the returns from 2016-2020.  Here are the differences by sector:

* CHTR instead of GOOG
* WBA instead of TGT
* GILD and BIIB instead of DHR and TMO
* LMT and RTX instead of HON and UNP
* AVGO and CRM instead of AAPL and NVDA

So yeah, 8 of the 20 stocks would be different.  But you know what?  That portfolio still beat the S&P 500 in 4 of the 5 years from 2016-2020, with about 2x the total return.

author: DPurp4
body:
If you're day trading AMD, good for you. If you're buying and holding AMD, quick question - why go with AMD over all the other semiconductor stocks? Anything in particular that gives AMD a leg up over NVDA, AVGO, TXN, INTC etc?

Just curious, I'm a potential buyer but not quite sold on it yet

author: kkInkr
body:
SMH, ADI, AMAT, ASML, ATEYY, AVGO, HIMX, INTT,  KLAC, LRCX, LSCC, MPWR, MU, NXPI, POWI,  PXLW, QCOM, QRVO, SIMO, SWKS, TER,

besides the usual AMD, INTC, NVDA, and TSM. Those 4 imo are outdated.  SMH is the ETF.

Circuitry, CDNS, SNPS, ANSS, they are being ignored, but have dominant roles, imo.

author: Elite003
body: I thought it was AVGO

author: No_Werewolf_1214
body:
Being dragged into tech choppiness, yup. Pulling back after a big pop post-earnings, most definitely. But too expensive? Not in my opinion. That’s one of the things that drew my attention to QCOM at first - how undervalued they are for what they currently are and what they are moving quickly into over these next few quarters. I honestly think it’s one of the best value plays in the market and one of the most well positioned growth plays at the same time. 

Just one data point, but telling: 

P/E of popular semis:
QCOM - 19.21 
NXPI - 127.22
AVGO - 51.41
TSM - 30.84
NVDA - 83.2 

...you get the idea. QCOM is one of the best valued (by far) plus growth plus monopolized patent power plus fundamentals. 

But your points about tech hassle spilling over are valid for sure. QCOM should be less impacted bc it’s not overvalued and it has killer cash flow and inflation protection. The major hurdle honestly seems to be it just not being a sexy meme stock or a flashy boom/bust type position. So depends how much love and interest the market gives it, but June/July entry or not minding boring middle of the road performance (i’m guessing) until around then is when you’d want to get options and shares positioned for max advantage. 


(That was long winded but hopefully helpful. Sorry if i told you shit you already knew lol).

author: WoodpeckerAlarmed239
body:
Most of the FANG stocks because I didn't see the value in the ad revenue. And then I always thought the prices were too high. I did buy AAPL in 2016 after realizing how many people pay big money for those phones and accessories, even people working low income jobs made room in the budget. 

But the one I had and sold was Broadcom. It would have been a 4 bagger right now. That one I think about just because I let it slip through my fingers.

author: daviddjg0033
body:
Same with TZA (IWM bearish 3x ETN.)
I am long NVDA with calendar calls and diagonals.
Usually stock split is a sell news event after a huge run but NVDA has not mooned.  AMD share buyback, AVGO chugging along.
I want TSMC and LCRX to round out my holdings- I sold for profit but want back in shares.  When AAPL and TSLA split I had baby shares and calls- a contrarian view.

author: trenderizer
body:
Tip of the day:  The best traps are those neat long-term trends. The love is strong, and so few have the courage to break-up.  
Likely happening right now in the semiconductor space, starting with AVGO.  
Chart: https://twitter.com/EyesOnTSX/status/1392121807294042114?s=20
